The Voyager program, launched by NASA in 1977, consisted of two robotic probes, Voyager 1 and Voyager 2, designed to study the outer Solar System. They have since accomplished their missions and are now in extended mission mode, making them the longest-operating spacecraft in history. Both Voyagers have encountered Jupiter and Saturn, while Voyager 2 went on to explore Uranus and Neptune. Their data has significantly contributed to our understanding of these giant planets and their moons.
Which of the following statements best summarizes the unique achievement of the Voyager 2 probe?
A. It was the first probe to reach Jupiter.
B. It is the only spacecraft to have visited Uranus and Neptune.
C. It operated for the shortest duration among all space probes.
D. It was the last spacecraft to leave the solar system.

Let's dive into this question about the Voyager program. So, the Voyager missions were really groundbreaking. Launched in 1977, these two probes, Voyager 1 and Voyager 2, were sent to explore the outer regions of our solar system. They've been up there for decades now, still sending back data, which is just amazing.

First off, both Voyager 1 and Voyager 2 checked out Jupiter and Saturn. But Voyager 2 did something extra special—it kept going and visited Uranus and Neptune too. That's a big deal because those are the only two planets in our solar system that Voyager 2 has visited; no other spacecraft has been there.

Now, the question is asking which statement best summarizes Voyager 2's unique achievement. Let's look at the options:

A. It was the first probe to reach Jupiter.

 Hmm, actually, Voyager 1 and Voyager 2 both reached Jupiter around the same time, but there were earlier probes that reached Jupiter, like Pioneer 10 and 11. So, this can't be the unique achievement.

B. It is the only spacecraft to have visited Uranus and Neptune.

 That sounds promising. Since Voyager 2 is the only one that went to Uranus and Neptune, that seems like a unique achievement.

C. It operated for the shortest duration among all space probes.

 That doesn't make sense because the Voyagers have been operating for a very long time, not the shortest duration.

D. It was the last spacecraft to leave the solar system.

 Actually, Voyager 1 has left the solar system and entered interstellar space, and Voyager 2 is expected to do so soon, but it hasn't yet. So, this option isn't accurate.

Considering these points, option B seems to be the correct answer. Voyager 2 is unique because it's the only spacecraft that has visited Uranus and Neptune.

But just to be thorough, let's think about it again. Is there any other spacecraft that has visited Uranus and Neptune besides Voyager 2? From what I know, the answer is no. The Voyager program was the first and so far the only one to explore those outer planets.

Also, regarding option A, Pioneer 10 arrived at Jupiter in 1973, and Pioneer 11 did the same in 1974, so Voyager 2 wasn't the first to reach Jupiter.

Option C is definitely not correct because the Voyagers have set records for the longest-operating spacecraft.

Option D is incorrect because Voyager 1 has already left the heliosphere, and Voyager 2 is still within it, although nearing the edge.

Therefore, the best answer is B: It is the only spacecraft to have visited Uranus and Neptune.

This highlights Voyager 2's unique contribution to space exploration by being the lone visitor to these distant ice giants.

**Final Answer**

\[ \boxed{B} \]
